title: Remove the Rule Against Intentional Feeding
body:
Why? Well, to put it simply...

You're making a big stink over something that doesn't even exist. There's no such thing as intentional feeders. Everyone gives it their best. It's just that their best isn't always good enough. So, yeah, the rule against intentional feeding is absurd and needs to go, not only because it's a rule against something that doesn't even exist, but I can't even imagine how many innocent players have gotten banned from the game all because they get killed a lot.

replies.body: It'd be great if this were always the truth, but sadly there are some times when some players feel the need to turn to the dark side and begin throwing games either out of anger or for 'fun'. Since it still happens sometimes and can be attributed to bots as well, I don't think that system or rule will be going anywhere.

Well, it should. That way, people can't accuse innocent players of intentional feeding or threaten to report them for it. You don't report people for things that don't exist. If a player dies a lot, they're just having a bad time. Happens to everyone. ...Which, now that I've said it out loud, makes me feel kinda stupid for repeatedly uninstalling the game because I'm kill fodder most of the time. But, on the other hand, you can't really blame me for getting upset. It's one thing to get a killed a couple of times, but to get killed again and again and again with no end in sight? That would upset anybody. Bottom line, I'm sticking with my belief that kill-feeding doesn't exist and that there shouldn't be a rule against it.

If you are inexperienced in the game, play against bots. Learn how to play the game without dying every 40 seconds due to extremely aggressive actions. You shouldn't have any more than 2 deaths in any bot game. If you are, you should learn and know the reasons for your deaths at that point. Learn when you should play passive, and when it's a good time to play aggressive. If you're constantly being killed to the point where you feed in the majority of your games, it's usually due to things you could have avoided, but didn't care or were too slow to avoid. Intentional feeding exists, whether or not you want to believe it.
No, it does not. Yes, I make mistakes every now and again, but it's never intentional. Everyone slips up once in a while, it's a basic fact of life.
Whether or not you believe yourself to intentionally feed is far from the point. It exists, whether or not you do.

Riot doesn't ban people for getting killed a lot. Riot bans people for intentionally spending 20 minutes (or more) running it down a single lane the second they get up (i.e. they revive at the base, and they immediately click to walk to the enemy nexus - and they don't stop until the enemy kills them).

Riot also bans players who do that for any *part* of a game.

They do not ban players simply for high death counts - they ban people who are intentionally dying to the enemy in an attempt to troll.

Okay, well, hardly anyone seems to be able to tell the difference. I myself have been accused of intentional feeding several times. It's not like that. I don't feed myself to an enemy champion. They either outsmart me and kill me or they catch me when I try to run and kill me then. Either way, I don't feed and I wish people would stop accusing me of feeding.

Intentional feeding: Player A runs down mid level 3. They run past the enemy champion without touching them. They run into the range of the enemy turret and stand there while the enemy champion is attacking them. They do not retaliate to either the champion or the turret both killing them. They die for no reason. They repeat the process, thus feeding their opponent. Does it happen? Quite often. But like you said, you deleted the game and don't play anymore. So. Why are you even here questioning something about a game you don't even play anymore? Obviously you don't know what happens in games.

Do people falsely accuse others of intentional feeding? Yeah, they're upset. Even if they decide to report them, it could be labeled as false reports. If for some reason it slips up and thinks you were intentionally feeding, you can dispute it with support, and they will review it, and most likely lift the punishment.

Here's something else.

Why are THEY upset? I'm the one getting murdered no matter what I throw at them and sometimes even getting killed before I having a chance to throw anything.

Other people in your team could be getting upset if you were to feed the enemy, because when done excessively, that enemy becomes powerful enough to impact other lanes and team fights. It makes the game harder on them as a result, and could decrease your chances of winning.

Well, I can't always help it. Enemy champions are always finding ways to outsmart me and kill me before I kill them. Sometimes, I get a break, but even now, I usually spend a lot of time being kill fodder despite my best efforts.

If you're playing to the best of your ability and still losing, then you're not intentionally feeding.

That however does not mean that intentional feeding does not exist on a general level.
Tell that to the other guys. They think every single player who gets killed a lot is a feeder, including those who try, but still fail.
I may not be playing anymore right now, but that doesn't mean I can't question parts of the game. And I've played enough games to know what can happen.

You're not asking a question, you're trying to argue that something doesn't exist when it clearly does. Nobody here is specifically saying that YOU are intentionally feeding, but that others do on a daily basis.
How do you do that?

Have you been *banned* for intentionally feeding? If so, you were intentionally feeding. If you're just being accused of it, don't worry because the system doesn't ban unless you are actually intentionally feeding.

I haven't been banned. At least, not that I know of. Keep in mind, I got rid of the game and haven't been back since. But it still irks me that anyone would go and accuse me of it. I've never been one to let people win. When I play a game--any game--I always give 100% and nothing less. It's just that my 100% doesn't seem to be enough most of the time.

Just a heads-up. I'm returning to League of Legends. I just need to do three things.

Stop getting so mad over getting killed a lot. Other players get killed a lot and they're still there playing, even with the false accusations of feeding.

Keep honing my skills so I can get killed less and maybe even end more games with more kills than deaths. I know there's ways to outsmart those enemy champions. I've done it before.

Get it through my head that the enemy champions are just a barrier to the main goal. It's the enemy Nexus we really want.

But, I'm still calling for the removal of the rule against feeding. There's no such thing as intentional feeding.

Many people go negative every day if you're only looking at kills and deaths. If you include assists and look at the overall KDR, the average is just above 2:1, so you should put your aim around there. For example, if you were 4/9/15, it shows you were in a good amount of team fights, but weren't necessarily the person who got the last hit out, and were probably being focused by the enemy because they might have seen your champion as a threat. It may not be the best looking score, but it's about average. It varies based on what role you're playing of course. I've had games where literally all 4 of the other players on my team went negative, and below a 2:1 KDR, but we still stuck together and pulled out for a win. Sometimes all you need is one good team fight and the will to push all the way. Regardless of what you think though, intentional feeding does exist, and it ruins the game for other players. Intentional feeding is when players intentionally suicide and give free kills, and often happens because they're either trolling or are upset with one of their teammates. Simply having a bad game is not worthy of a report, but it's an attitude that is usually reflected in their chat behavior. When people say "kill me, free kill" or "open mid" or "i gave you that turret" - those are signs of giving up and letting the enemy take free kills or objectives, and is not a behavior that other players would support.

Just less than a week ago, 2 opponents in my game decided to spend the majority of the game running through jungle and directly towards my fountain. They played Nidalee and Quinn, and both built speed items. They cheered every time they made it to our fountain, and flamed every time we stopped them. They did that about 20 times throughout the course of the game. So, tell me that it doesn't exist.

The two players were clearly stuck on a poorly-planned strategy, got happy when it looked like it was working, and got really upset when it went wrong. The way I see it, the thing to punish them for is the verbal abuse they flung. That was certainly not OK. Feeding? I'll say it as many times as I need to. Intentional feeding doesn't exist.
